I think it's called "magnetoconstriction" and whenever the forces acting on a piece of metal, even if due to the increase in the intensity of a magnetic field penetrating it, get high enough, the metal will begin to behavior like a fluid and can deform. You could get the same effect by just clamping a coin between two metal cylinders with a slightly smaller diameter than the coin and hammering the edges of the coin inward. Then you would remove the coin and repeat the procedure using two metal cylinders with a slightly smaller diameter and so on until you got the coin down to the size you wanted. That is how skilled jewelers would do it.

True Explanation- The coin is the size it is because of the quantity of energy in each atom. The distance the atoms are apart depends on this energy value. Less than 1% of the metal is "solid" the rest is space. If the energy value is increased ( e.g. by heating it in a flame ) the coin will expand (the atoms have moved further apart) . When the electromagnetic field is applied a massive shock is produced that displaces a portion of the energy within each atom. The reduction in energy causes the distance between each atom to diminish, the coin is smaller. A similar effect occurs if the coin is cooled (taking energy away from the atoms) – it goes smaller.

This is basically how Z-pinch fusion devices work, these aren't the typical tokamak devices that most people think of.

A fuel pellet containing duterium and tritium is placed on a little platform and many thin tungsten wires are threaded vertically around it in concentric circles.
A large current is passed through the wires (somewhere in the region of 3-5MA) and this causes the wires to almost instantly vaporize due to the resistive heat generated. At the same time the large current also induces a huge magnetic field around where the wires used to be. The vaporized wires are now in a plasma state and the same inward force (the JxB force) causes this plasma to fly inwards towards the fuel pellet.

When the ring of plasma hits the pellet it crushes and heats the D-T fuel until the density and temperature is high enough for nuclear fusion to take place. The D-T fuse together and the pellet explodes outwards, releasing many extremely energetic neutrons (~13.7MeV iirc) which can be captured in a water bath sorrounding the reactor.

The water heats up and when expanded into steam it can drive turbines to produce energy.
